column4: Hi, I've got a question.  How is it that Ubuntu gets away with having the slogan "it just works"?  So far, in my 3 days using it, I've realized that basically it just doesn't work.  I have multiple debilitating errors, and while there seems to be a number of how-to's for "solutions" to these problems, none of them actually work either.  So now I've got windows XP, which does what I need it to do, albeit slowly and brokenly.
and on the other hand there's ubuntu
how does ubuntu get away with "it just works"??
where do you see "It just works?"

Broadcom does not release ANY code in ANY form to allow their stuff to work with anything except Windows. this is NOT a Linux problem. it's a Broadcom problem. and if you don't like it, vote with your wallet.
how is "we can't see how the hardware works so we have to design solutions in the dark with our hands tied" a lousy excuse?
the better question is "why do you feel people are obligated to help you for free?"
if you'd like a guaranteed response we sell commercial support contracts.
just because the device is displayed does not mean Linux can actually use it. are you able to connect with that card?
remove the GNOME networking panel applet. then reboot.
